default.prompt: What is the default 'flexDirection' in React Native?
default.explanation: Unlike the web (where it defaults to 'row'), React Native defaults to 'column' to match the vertical nature of mobile screens.
default.interviewTip: This is the #1 mistake web developers make when starting with React Native.

default.prompt: Which property aligns items along the 'main axis'?
default.explanation: justifyContent aligns children along the main axis. If the direction is column, it aligns vertically; if row, it aligns horizontally.
default.interviewTip: Remember: Justify = Main Axis, Align = Cross Axis.

default.prompt: Which property aligns items along the 'cross axis'?
default.explanation: alignItems aligns children along the axis perpendicular to the main axis.
default.interviewTip: By default, alignItems is set to 'stretch' in React Native.

default.prompt: What does 'flex: 1' mean for a component?
options: It sets the width to 1 pixel
It tells the component to fill all available space in its parent
It limits the component to 10% of the screen
default.explanation: A component with 'flex: 1' will expand to fill all remaining space in its parent container.
default.interviewTip: If multiple siblings have 'flex: 1', they will share the space equally.

options: It allows an individual child to override the parent's 'alignItems' setting
It only works on the parent container
It is used for absolute positioning
default.explanation: While 'alignItems' is set on the parent, 'alignSelf' is set on a specific child to control its own alignment on the cross axis.
default.interviewTip: This is useful when you want one item centered but others stretched.

default.prompt: How do you handle elements that should go off-screen or wrap to the next line?
default.explanation: flexWrap: 'wrap' allows items that don't fit on the main axis to move to the next 'line'.

default.prompt: Which unit is used for dimensions (width/height) in React Native?
default.explanation: Dimensions in RN are unitless and represent density-independent pixels, which scale across different screen resolutions.
default.interviewTip: You can use percentages as strings (e.g., '50%'), but raw numbers are always dp.

default.prompt: What is the effect of 'position: absolute' in React Native?
options: It positions the element relative to the screen bounds
It positions the element relative to its nearest parent
It removes the element from the flexbox flow
It works exactly like in web CSS
default.explanation: Absolute positioning removes the element from the normal layout flow, allowing it to overlap other components.
default.interviewTip: Unlike web, you don't need 'position: relative' on the parent for 'absolute' to work on the child in RN; children are always positioned relative to their parent.

options: It maintains a fixed ratio between width and height
It calculates the brightness of the screen
default.explanation: aspectRatio is a unique RN property that ensures a component maintains a specific shape (e.g., 16/9) regardless of screen size.
default.interviewTip: This is incredibly helpful for responsive image containers.

default.prompt: How do you add space between siblings without using margins?
default.explanation: Modern React Native supports the 'gap' (and 'rowGap', 'columnGap') property, which adds space strictly between items.
default.interviewTip: This is a newer feature that saves you from writing complex margin logic for the last item in a list.

default.prompt: What is the difference between 'padding' and 'margin'?
options: Padding is outside the border; margin is inside
Padding is inside the component's boundary; margin is space outside it
There is no difference in React Native
Margin only works for Text components
default.explanation: Padding creates space inside the component, affecting the placement of children. Margin creates space around the component, affecting its distance from siblings.
default.interviewTip: The 'Box Model' in RN is slightly simpler than web as it doesn't have as many border-box/content-box complexities.

default.prompt: How can you get the screen's width and height dynamically?
default.explanation: The Dimensions API (or useWindowDimensions hook) provides the current screen size.
default.interviewTip: Use the 'useWindowDimensions' hook for better responsiveness, as it updates automatically on screen rotation.

default.prompt: Which justifyContent value spreads items evenly with equal space around them?
default.explanation: 'space-evenly' ensures the space between items and the space to the edges is exactly the same.
default.interviewTip: Contrast this with 'space-around', where the edge space is half the size of the middle space.

default.prompt: What is 'z-index' used for in React Native?
options: Controlling the stack order of overlapping elements
default.explanation: z-index allows you to control which element appears 'on top' when they overlap due to absolute positioning.
default.interviewTip: On Android, z-index sometimes requires the 'elevation' property to work correctly with shadows.

default.prompt: Does React Native support percentage-based heights/widths?
default.explanation: React Native supports percentage strings for dimensions, which are calculated based on the parent's size.
default.interviewTip: Note that Flex is usually preferred over percentages for fluid layouts.

default.prompt: What happens if a parent has no 'height' but the child has 'flex: 1'?
options: The child fills the whole screen
The child will have its natural size
default.explanation: If a parent doesn't have a defined size (or isn't flexed itself), a child with 'flex: 1' has no space to expand into.
default.interviewTip: This is a common reason why components 'disappear'.

default.prompt: Which property allows you to set space at the start/end of a layout, respecting LTR/RTL languages?
default.explanation: Using 'Start' and 'End' instead of 'Left' and 'Right' makes your app automatically compatible with Right-to-Left (RTL) languages like Arabic or Hebrew.
default.interviewTip: Modern mobile development favors Start/End for better internationalization (i18n).
